newsitem.title: UK: Korean airliner worth around $60 mln, insurers say.
newsitem.headline: Korean airliner worth around $60 mln, insurers say.

text.p: A Korean Air Lines (KAL) Boeing 747 which crashed yesterday on Guam in the Pacific had an insured value of some $60 million, London insurance sources told Reuters on Wednesday.
Broker for the 1984 built aircraft is London based CT Bowring, a part of Marsh & McLennan.
A spokeswoman for Bowring said the original insurer is Oriental Fire and Marine Insurance Company Limited in Seoul.
Market sources said the aircraft would be widely reinsured on the aviation market, adding that Oriental Fire and Marine would have retained only a very small part of the risk.
Reinsurance in the London market was led by Chaucer syndicate 173 and Murray Lawrence syndicate 824 at Lloyd's of London.
Underwriter for the syndicates John Butler said they were sending a surveyor and a solicitor to help to establish the circumstances of the crash.
Insurers said their main concerns were with the survivors and the families of those killed. They were unwilling to talk about possible compensation at this stage.
There were 231 passengers and 23 crewmembers on the Boeing 747, which crashed into a hillside near Guam's main airport overnight.
The latest casualty figures from U.S. authorities put the number of survivors at 30, with 69 bodies recovered and 155 people still missing.
The aircraft, registration HL7468, was powered by four Pratt & Whitney JT9D engines. Pratt & Whitney is owned by United Technologies .
KAL is an affiliate of South Korea's Hanjin Group.
There have been a spate of aviation accidents in the last week, starting with the crash of a FedEx MD11 freighter.
No lives were lost in that incident, but the cost to insurers is expected to be $115 million.
Other incidents occurred at Manchester airport in Britain, Florence airport in Italy and Douala airport in Cameroon.
The ATR-42 involved in the Florence crash, in which the pilot died, has been declared a total constructive loss and was insured for $14.5 million, one London aviation underwriter said.
There were no serious casualties in the Manchester and Douala accidents, but Air Afrique has told Reuters that its Boeing 737 was largely destroyed by fire at Douala.
The 1969 built aircraft, registration TUTAV, would be worth around $3.0 million, aviation sources said.
